comments:
I downloaded Mylar 0.4.1. I am running Eclipse 3.1 (build id: M20050929-0840) on Mac OS X 10.4.2 
with Java 5.0 release 1 on a powerbook G4.  The mylar plugins are all installed in an external install 
location (i.e. not inside the main eclipse/ folder).

Whenever I click on anything related to Mylar, I get the message 'The chosen operation is not currently 
available'. None of the views work and the preferences pages don't show up either. The message in 
every case is that it cannot find some UI class or another. As a result, Mylar basically cannot be used at 
all.

On attempting to show the Mylar Tasks view, I get the following stack trace. This is true for the other 
views too - all that changes is the class that cannot be found:

The problem here seems to be that the Mylar classes are failing to load.  The UI
stuff comes from plugin.xml files, which don't require classes to load, hence
the "not available" message.  You've probably done this already, but
double-check to make sure that you are using the Eclipse 3.1 update site, since
Mylar 3.2 won't load on Eclipse 3.1.

Assuming that's not the case, could I ask you to close Eclipse, delete your
<workspace>/.metadata/.log file, start Eclipse, try the action and then attach
that file to this report?  

I don't test on a Mac, so appreciate you help in debugging this.

Created an attachment (id=29977)
Eclipse log file containing stack trace when Mylar view is activated.

Attached is the log file. I renamed it to eclipse.log because making hidden
files show up in Mac OS X's file chooser is a pain.

This following line indicates that you are almost certainly running on a 1.4 VM,
and Mylar requires a Java 5 VM.  The way to check is by going to Help -> About
Eclipse SDK -> Configuration Details and checking that the java.vm.version is
1.5.  Let me know whethre that's the case.

I'm going to add this as a note to the FAQ.  

Caused by: java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError:
org/eclipse/mylar/tasklist/MylarTasklistPlugin (Unsupported major.minor version
49.0)

You are right. Although my projects are all running 1.5, Eclipse itself isn't. This seems to be default 1.5 
installation behavior on Mac OS X (it does not replace 1.4.2). So here's some steps for people to make 
1.5.0 default which you can add to the FAQ if you wish:

As root do:
cd /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Versions
mv CurrentJDK Old.JDK
ln -s 1.5.0 CurrentJDK

Or use the -vm argument by editing the plist.info file. 

Thanks for the help!

Thanks for the pointer, I've linked to it in the new FAQ entry: 

http://eclipse.org/mylar/doc/faq.html#install-failure

(In reply to comment #4)
> As root do:
> cd /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Versions
> mv CurrentJDK Old.JDK
> ln -s 1.5.0 CurrentJDK


Another way of doing this is to make a jre symblink like desescribed bellow:

ln -s /System/Library/Frameworks/JavaVM.framework/Versions/1.5/Home \
./Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/jre

From what I know, it is most of the time not a good ting to change stuff under /System


-Kaj :)
